descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description: Mike Bibby had 25 points and seven assists as the Sacramento Kings improved to 13-1 at home, beating the Detroit Pistons 102-98 on Tuesday night.
article.headline: Sacramento 102, Detroit 98
article.linkText: Home rule: Kings top Pistons for 13-1 home mark
article.story:
SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) -- Until Chris Webber finds his groove in the Sacramento Kings' lineup, they'll try to keep winning with the type of team effort that kept them among the NBA's elite during his absence. Mike Bibby led such an outing with 25 points and seven assists Tuesday night as the Kings improved to 13-1 at home, beating the Detroit Pistons 102-98. Webber, wearing a scowl throughout the meeting with his hometown team, had 19 points and 14 rebounds as the Kings held off the Pistons in a tense fourth quarter despite a season-high 35 points from Jerry Stackhouse, including 13 in the fourth. "Chris has been out six or eight weeks, and until he gets back into his game, we'll all have to stay together," said Peja Stojakovic, who had 20 points. "He can't do it all right now. We all have to do it." Webber, who met with team doctors after the game and did not comment, never once cracked his infectious smile and sometimes showed frustration with his teammates in his sixth game since returning from his sprained ankle. He saved the rest of his emotions for a shouting match with Stackhouse that earned technical fouls for both players. Still, the Kings were good enough together to hang on for their sixth straight home victory, even if it wasn't the type of blowout that fans have often seen at Arco Arena this season. The Kings led throughout the second half but never pulled away. "There were times we really could have opened this game up, and we didn't stay with it defensively, and that allowed them to hang around," Sacramento coach Rick Adelman said. Detroit got within 96-93 on Stackhouse's acrobatic three-point play with 60 seconds left, but former Sacramento crowd favorite Jon Barry missed a free throw to give the Kings some breathing room. Ben Wallace and Barry cut the lead to two points with late baskets, but Doug Christie and Peja Stojakovic hit six free throws in the final 22 seconds to seal Sacramento's ninth win in 12 games. "It was a tough loss because we played OK, but they always played with a cushion," Stackhouse said. "We couldn't get over the hump. (In the second half) we were struggling, so there was a little more of an onus on me trying to get to the basket." Bibby, in an impressive performance, made nine of his first 11 shots and also went 6-for-7 at the free throw line. Stojakovic, returning from two games missed with back spasms, had 12 points in the second half of Sacramento's sixth straight win over Detroit. Webber missed seven straight shots at one point but had five assists while getting his teammates more involved in the offense. He also didn't back down from Stackhouse after what Webber perceived as a cheap foul. "It's all in the heat of the battle," Stackhouse said. "Out there, you don't have any friends." Chucky Atkins had 12 points, while Barry had 10 in his homecoming. Relying almost entirely on Stackhouse for offense in the fourth quarter, the Pistons lost their third straight road game despite giving the Kings one of their few tests at home this season. "Our defense down the stretch of the last six or eight minutes was really good, but the first 40 weren't good enough to play against an offensive team like this," Detroit coach Rick Carlisle said. "It's hard to get in a hole and dig out of it, but we were close." Stojakovic, sporting a short new haircut, seemed to be struggling with his shot but made all eight of his free throws. Barry, traded to Detroit for Mateen Cleaves during the summer, still is immensely popular at Arco Arena. He got a standing ovation when he checked into the game late in the first quarter, and another ovation when he hit a 3-pointer from three steps behind the line. "It was pretty strange, but I really had a good time," Barry said. "I had a wrestling match with Scot (Pollard), and Vlade (Divac) was talking smack, like he always does."

Game notes
Despite back-to-back losses last week, the Kings still are off to the best start in franchise history at 19-7. The 1951-52 Rochester Royals also went 19-7, a mark matched by last season's Kings. ... Before the game, the Kings activated Lawrence Funderburke from the injured list and waived Jabari Smith. ... Arco Arena fans chanted "Barry! Barry!" during pregame introductions, but Barry didn't start. ... Ben Wallace, a 43 percent free throw shooter, airballed a foul shot in the first quarter. ... Cleaves didn't play.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
